ResponseText: What does that have to do with a mythical flood about 4500 years ago? It cudda been! Where does the article indicate that this water ever came to the surface? And if it did, why did it and how and why is it back below the earth. Science is more than just making claims about unrelated hypotheses. You should be laughed at (rightfully) for making such claims without offering any mechanism that brought the water to the surface, dispersed the heat, and returned it to the mantle. Just because you want to believe it doesn't mean it isn't silly. As has been pointed out, the water, if it came to the surface, would have been superheated and flashed to steam immediately. There is also the fact that the condensation of water in the atmosphere into rain would also have released enough heat to boil the ocean. In order to flood the earth would above the mountains would have required more than 4 times the water now present on earth. If you try to claim that the mountains were just low hills that arose after the flood, then you run into even more heat problems, since mountains are either tectonic (which causes heat) or volcanic (the result of the heat from tectonics). Then you have to find a solution to the problem of the various biota that had to migrate across oceans - if you wish to claim that the continents were all together and them moved at super speeds, then you again run into heat problems. It makes one wonder how you can fall for this stuff as science without even bothering to learn reality.
